p: As part of the evolutionary process, viruses change their pathogenesis, virulence and transmissibility characteristics. As seen in the evolution of influenza virus [ 5], the multistrain dynamics of norovirus is considered to involve antigenic drift (i.e., changes in epitopes within the capsid P2 domain) and shift (e.g., overlapping recombination in open reading frame, ORF 1, and ORF 2), which allows the virus to escape the pressure of human immunity [ 6– 9]. For instance, genogroup II (GII) and genotype 4 (GII.4) strains have caused at least six global epidemics [ 10– 15] during the past 20 years, and have experienced antigenic evolution [ 6, 7]. The newly emerged genotype GII.17 is no exception in this context: it has been the predominant strain in a number of recent disease outbreaks [ 16– 18].
